#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER XVII --
#Text=THE PHANTOM CAPTURED
#Text=Surprise held Tom and his friends almost spellbound for the moment .
#Text=The young inventor 's hand went toward the pocket where he carried his revolver .
#Text=Mr. Jenks , who had the only other weapon , sought to draw it , but he was stopped by a gesture of one of the two men with guns .
#Text=“ Hold on , strangers ! ” the man cried .
#Text=“ I know what you 're up to ! Better not try to draw anything -- it might not be healthy .
#Text=Now , then , who are you , and what do you want ? ”
#Text=The question came rather as a surprise , at least to Tom and Mr. Jenks .
#Text=They had taken it for granted that these men -- if they were the diamond makers -- would know Mr. Jenks , and guess at his errand in coming back to Phantom Mountain .
#Text=But , it seemed , that they took them all for casual strangers .
#Text=No one answered for a moment .
#Text=Tom caught the eye of Mr. Jenks , and there was a look of hope in it .
#Text=If ever there was a time for strategy , it was now .
#Text=Evidently Munson , the stowaway on the airship , had not yet been able to send a warning to his confederates .
#Text=And neither of the two men recognized Mr. Jenks as the man who had been defrauded of his rights .
#Text=It might be possible to conceal the real object of the adventurers until they had time to formulate a plan of action .
#Text=“ Well , ” exclaimed the man with the gun , impatiently , “ I ask you folks a question .
#Text=What do you want ? ”
#Text=Fortunately , neither Mr. Damon nor Mr. Parker replied .
#Text=The former because he deferred to Tom and Mr. Jenks , and the scientist because he was busy inspecting some curious rocks he picked up .
#Text=As it turned out this was the luckiest thing he could have done .
#Text=It lent color to what Mr. Jenks said a moment later .
#Text=“ What are you doing up here ? ” demanded the man again .
#Text=“ Do n't you know this is private property ? ”
#Text=“ We -- we were just looking around , ” answered Mr. Jenks , which was true enough ; as far as it went .
#Text=“ Prospecting , ” added Tom .
#Text=“ After gold ? ” demanded the second man , suspiciously .
#Text=“ We 'd be glad to find some , ” retorted the lad .
#Text=At that moment Mr. Parker began breaking off bits of rock with a small geologist 's hammer which he carried .
#Text=The men with the guns looked at him .
#Text=“ So you think you 'll find gold up here ? ” asked the one who had first spoken .
#Text=“ Is there any ? ” inquired Tom , trying to make his voice sound eager .
#Text=“ Nary a bit , strangers , ” was the answer , and the two men laughed heartily .
#Text=“ Now , we do n't want to seem harsh , ” went on the man who seemed to be the spokesman , “ but you 'd better get away from here .
#Text=This is private ground , and dangerous too -- how 'd you ever get up the trail -- we heard it was destroyed . ”
#Text=“ There is still a narrow path , ” said Mr. Jenks .
#Text=“ We came up that -- the lightning and landslide have n't left much of it , though . ”
#Text=Mr. Parker looked quickly up from the rocks at which he was tapping with his small hammer .
#Text=“ You have terrific lightning up here , ” he said .
#Text=“ I am much interested in it , from a scientific standpoint .
#Text=I predict that some day the entire mountain will be destroyed by a blast from the sky . ”
#Text=“ I hope it wo n't be right away , ” spoke one of the men .
#Text=“ Now I guess you folks had better be leaving while there 's a path left to go down by . ”

#Text=“ Might I ask , ” broke in Mr. Parker , as calmly as though he was lecturing to a class of students , “ might I ask if you have noticed any peculiar effect of the lightning up here on the summit of the mountain ?
#Text=Does it fuse and melt rocks , so to speak ? ”
#Text=“ What 's that ? ” cried the spokesman , with a sudden flash of anger .
#Text=The two men looked at each other .
#Text=“ I wanted to know , merely for scientific reasons , whether the lightning up here ever melted rocks ? ” repeated Mr. Jenks .
#Text=“ Well , whether it 's for scientific reasons or for any other , I 'm not going to answer you ! ” snapped the man .
#Text=“ It 's none of your affair what the lightning does up here .
#Text=Now you 'd all better ' vamoose' -- clear out ! ”
#Text=“ All right -- we 'll go , ” said Tom , quickly , at the same time motioning to Mr. Jenks to agree with him .
#Text=The eyes of the young inventor were roving about .
#Text=He saw what looked like a second trail , leading down the mountain , from the far side of the cave .
#Text=He was convinced now that there was another way to get to it .
#Text=Possibly they might find it .
#Text=At any rate nothing more could be done now .
#Text=They must go back , for the cavern was too well guarded to attempt to enter it by force -- at least just yet .
#Text=“ Yes , we 'll go back , ” assented Mr. Jenks .
#Text=Mr. Parker was tapping away at the rocks .
#Text=He looked toward the black mouth of the big cave .
#Text=On what corresponded to the roof of it , some distance back from the entrance , he saw a slender metal rod sticking up into the air .
#Text=“ May I ask if that 's a lightning rod ? ” he inquired innocently .
#Text=“ If it is , I should like to ask about its action in a mountain that is so impregnated with iron ore .
#Text=“ You may ask until you get tired ! ” cried the spokesman , again showing unreasoning anger , “ but you 'll get no answer from us .
#Text=Now get away from here before we do something desperate .
#Text=You 're on private ground and you 're not wanted .
#Text=Clear out while you have the chance . ”
